unit_designation: 1ère Brigade Française Libre (1st Free French Brigade Group)

commander.name: Marie-Pierre Koenig
commander.previous_service: Commanded Free French forces at Bir Hakeim (May-June 1942), distinguished defense against 5 Axis divisions with 3,700 men for 16 days

command.headquarters_location: Western Desert, Egypt (attached to 7th Armoured Division)

Crusader Mk III.notes: 1st Free French Tank Company (Fighting French Tank Company)

Ordnance QF 6-pounder (57mm) Mk II.notes: British-supplied AT gun, entered service May 1942

Canon de 75 mle 1897 (portée).notes: French WWI-era field gun used in AT role, truck-mounted

Canon de 75 mle 1897.notes: French WWI-era field gun used in AT role

Canon de 50mm mle 1937.notes: French AT gun, unserviceable at El Alamein

Ordnance QF 25-pounder (dual role).notes: British field gun used in emergency AT role

Hotchkiss M1929 13.2mm.notes: French heavy machine gun in AA role

Thompson M1928A1.notes: Used by officers, NCOs, tank crews

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for sustained operations. Brigade operates under British Eighth Army logistics system with supplies from Alexandria (450km). Primary constraint: dependence on British supply chain for ammunition, fuel, and replacement equipment. French-specific equipment (FM 24/29, MAS-36) has limited resupply.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal plain and rocky desert (Western Desert, Egypt)

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 1st Battalion, French Foreign Legion (1er Bataillon, Légion Étrangère)
subordinate_units.notes: Part of 13th Demi-Brigade of Foreign Legion (13e DBLE)

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 2nd Battalion, French Foreign Legion (2e Bataillon, Légion Étrangère)
subordinate_units.notes: Part of 13th Demi-Brigade of Foreign Legion (13e DBLE)

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 3rd Battalion, Infanterie Marine Pacifique (Bataillon du Pacifique)
subordinate_units.notes: Pacific Marine Battalion, veterans of Bir Hakeim

subordinate_units.unit_designation: 1st Free French Artillery Regiment (1er Régiment d'Artillerie Française Libre)
1st Free French Field Company Engineers (1ère Compagnie du Génie)

subordinate_units.notes: British unit attached for fire support

composition: 1st Free French Tank Company (12x Crusader tanks)
Portée Troop, 1st Morocco Spahis (4x 75mm AT, 1x 50mm AT)

tactical_doctrine.role: Independent Free French brigade group operating under British command. Mission: infantry assault and defensive operations in desert warfare, with organic tank, anti-tank, artillery, and reconnaissance assets. Proven capability in sustained defensive operations (Bir Hakeim siege, May-June 1942).
special_capabilities: Multi-national composition (French, North African, Pacific Islander troops) with high cohesion
Veteran of Bir Hakeim defense (held against 5 Axis divisions for 16 days)
Combined arms integration with organic tanks, armored cars, artillery
High morale and élan (Free French volunteers)
tactical_innovations: Flying Column concept: mobile combined-arms force with tanks, armored cars, portée AT guns
Integration of British equipment with French tactical doctrine
Flexible defensive tactics learned at Bir Hakeim
known_issues: Limited heavy equipment compared to British brigades
Dependence on British logistics and resupply
French-specific ammunition and parts difficult to obtain
Smaller tank company (12 tanks vs. British regiment of 40-50)
No organic heavy artillery (5.5-inch guns attached, not organic)
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Extensive desert operations experience since 1941. Troops acclimated to heat and water discipline. Vehicles modified for sand operations. Strong emphasis on mobile warfare and reconnaissance.

scenario_suitability: Second Battle of El Alamein (October 23, 1942) - XIII Corps sector
special_rules: High Morale: Free French volunteers, +1 morale in all situations
Desert Veterans: No penalties for desert terrain or heat
Bir Hakeim Heroes: +1 to defensive combat in prepared positions
Mixed Equipment: Maintenance rolls at -1 due to British/French equipment mix
British Logistics: Full supply when operating with Eighth Army, limited supply when independent
historical_engagements: Battle of Bir Hakeim (May 26 - June 11, 1942) - Defensive victory, held position
Second Battle of El Alamein (October 23 - November 11, 1942) - Offensive breakthrough

source: Nafziger Collection OOB File 942bjoc.pdf (El Alamein, 23 October 1942) - Equipment counts, organization structure
National WWII Museum: Forgotten Fights: The Free French at Bir Hacheim, May 1942 - Personnel strength, historical context
Britannica: Marie-Pierre Koenig biography - Commander information, Bir Hakeim defense
French Foreign Legion historical records - 13th DBLE strength at Bir Hakeim (957 men)
L'Ordre de la Libération: The French Army - Free French organization, 1st BFL structure

subordinate_unit_commanders.reason: Nafziger OOB file lists unit designations and equipment but not battalion/company commanders. Web sources focus on Koenig (brigade commander) but do not document subordinate commanders for 1942-Q3 period.
sources_checked: Nafziger Collection 942bjoc.pdf - No commander names below brigade level
National WWII Museum article - Mentions Amilakvari commanded 13th DBLE at Bir Hakeim (May-Jun 1942) but not October 1942
L'Ordre de la Libération - Organization structure only, no personnel names
Britannica Koenig biography - Brigade commander only
French Foreign Legion records - Unit organization, not individual commanders
subordinate_unit_commanders.mitigation: Check French military archives (Service Historique de la Défense) for 1er BFL personnel records October 1942. Alternately, accept gap if 78% confidence acceptable for brigade-level TO&E without subordinate commander names.

exact_vehicle_variants.reason: Nafziger does not specify exact armored car variants or truck models. Estimated based on British Eighth Army standard equipment tables and Free French known inventory 1942.
sources_checked: Nafziger 942bjoc.pdf - Lists 'Armored Car Squadron' without vehicle types
British Army equipment tables 1942 - Standard Eighth Army reconnaissance squadron composition
Free French forces equipment records - Known to use Marmon-Herrington and Humber from British supply
exact_vehicle_variants.mitigation: Variants estimated as Marmon-Herrington Mk II (primary) and Humber Mk II (command) based on British Eighth Army standard issue to reconnaissance squadrons 1942. Truck variants estimated from British supply records.
exact_vehicle_variants.estimate_method: Based on British Eighth Army standard equipment tables for reconnaissance squadrons and motorized infantry brigades, applied to Free French unit structure

exact_personnel_breakdown.reason: Nafziger provides equipment and unit structure but not detailed personnel counts. Web sources give brigade totals (~3,700 at Bir Hakeim, ~5,000 at later period) but not officer/NCO/enlisted breakdown.
sources_checked: Nafziger 942bjoc.pdf - Equipment only, no personnel numbers
National WWII Museum - Brigade total ~3,700-5,000 men, no breakdown
13th DBLE records - 957 men at Bir Hakeim (May 1942), growth by October unknown
French battalion organization tables - Standard structure used for estimation
exact_personnel_breakdown.mitigation: Personnel estimated at 3,850 total (mid-point between Bir Hakeim 3,700 and later 5,000) with officer/NCO/enlisted ratio based on standard French infantry brigade tables 1940-1942. Battalion strengths estimated at 850 (Foreign Legion) and 780 (Pacific Battalion) based on historical records.
exact_personnel_breakdown.estimate_method: Brigade total estimated from historical sources (3,700-5,000 range). Officer ratio 7.4%, NCO ratio 16.1%, enlisted 76.5% based on French Army infantry brigade organization tables 1940. Battalion strengths calculated from known 13th DBLE strength at Bir Hakeim plus estimated growth by October 1942.
